titlestmt.titleproper: Waco Civic Theatre records, Inclusive: 1931-2002, undated, Bulk: 1955-1995, undated

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Records Summary

physdesc.extent:
11 document boxes
2 OVZ document boxes
7 OVZ boxes
1 OVZ folder

did.abstract: The Waco Civic Theatre records document business operations and performances of the community volunteer theatre group from 1931-2020. Notable documents include minutes, programs, scrapbooks, photographs, clippings, and correspondence.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Waco Little Theatre was established in the 1920s and performed for a Waco audience from 1925 to 1936. The group went dormant until 1945 when Paul Baker, then Professor and Chair of the Baylor University Drama Department, worked with former members of the Little Theatre to create and charter the Waco Civic Theatre, Inc. The charter was granted by the State of Texas for 50 years, beginning in 1948.

In 1948, the Waco Civic Theater (WCT) began performing at Baylor University’s Little Theater and did so until budget cuts and increased productions at Baylor disallowed the use of facilities in 1951. WCT began performing in other places around Waco including Casa Blanca, the Shrine Ballroom, the National Guard Armory, and YWCA until a permanent home was established in 1958. Paul Baker worked with renowned theatre designer, James Hull Miller, to create the building on Lake Air Drive in Waco. In 1963 the building was commended by the Journal of the Royal Institute of British Architects. Since then, the building has undergone several additions and renovations.

Waco Civic Theatre currently produces six plays per year, including children’s productions. Local partnerships also allow the WCT to coordinate children’s theatre workshops and outreach programs. The WCT is currently a non-profit organization and receives funding through ticket sales, and has received several grants and donations from sources such as the Cooper Foundation, Waco Foundation, and an endowment funded by Frank Baird, Jr. of Buffalo, New York, in honor of his mother Mrs. Flora Cameron Baird.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Administrative series includes by-laws, correspondence, production materials, and minutes of the Waco Civic Theatre. Minutes are photocopies as the originals were retained by the organization. Production folders include information such as licensing for names, rights, music, and scripts in addition to seating information, ticket sales information, other financial records, press releases, contracts, correspondence, cast lists, and call sheets. Correspondence by Hilton H. Howell documents the construction of the Waco Civic Theatre building in the 1950s. Several folders also hold reference and design materials for the build in consultation with famed theater designer James Hull Miller.

The Publications series is primarily clippings, newsletters, and programs. The clippings include reviews, advertisements, and write-ups about the productions. Newsletters are under two names, “The Prompter” and “Upstaged.” They both document performances, announce upcoming auditions, and highlight the work of the theatre. Programs document the Waco Little Theatre from 1931-1936 and the Waco Civic Theatre from 1950-2002. There are also articles about Paul Baker.

The Scrapbooks and Audiovisual series comprise the bulk of the collection. The scrapbooks document a range of performances over forty years through photographs, programs, clippings, and other items. The Audiovisual series includes many photo negatives, photo slides, and photographs, in addition to a few audiocassettes, 16mm film reels, and reel to reel tapes. For the most part, negatives and slides are undated but, in some cases, correspond with photographs. Photographs often include multiple shows within a folder, this is recognized in folder titles by including show names and the month the show was performed. Several hand drawn oversize posters are also included. It is unclear whether these were used as decorations for the theatre or as part of a performance.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials were organized prior to this most recent processing. Audiovisual materials had been rehoused by type, scrapbooks were in oversize boxes, and other materials had new boxes. There was no discernible arrangement for written documents. Currently, the records are in four series: I. Administrative, II. Publications, III. Scrapbooks, and IV. Audiovisual.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Waco Civic Theatre records, Accession #2231, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Sylvia Hernandez. Released on 2021-02-12.

bibref.extref: “About WCT.” Waco Civic Theatre. Accessed 2020 October 2.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Administrative series, dated 1950-2002, includes by-laws, minutes, correspondence, production materials, and information on the design and construction of the Civic Theatre building. The series is arranged alphabetically and in good condition.

Theatre Design & Construction: Loft Addition Specifications
Waco Civic Theatre Guild Member Lists

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Publications series, dated 1931-2020, is composed primarily of clippings, newsletters, advertising materials, and theatre programs. The series is arranged alphabetically and is in good condition.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Scrapbooks series, dated 1950-1992, documents performances and the theatre through photographs, programs, and clippings. The series is arranged in chronological order and is in good condition.

did.unittitle: You Can’t Take It with You and Dracula

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Audiovisual series is dated 1958-1996 with a good amount of undated materials. The series is arranged alphabetically by media type, then chronologically within each medium. Media includes 16 mm film, audiocassettes, negatives, photographs, posters, reel to reels, and slides. The series is in good condition.
